caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 15.
Athalia vollenhoveni
. A & C, dorsal views. B & D, lateral views. A-B, male (P3586A_08), body length: 7.0 mm. C-D, female (P3586A_10), body length: 7.5 mm.

FIGURE 16. Life history of
Athalia vollenhoveni
. A, biotope at Tarmaber Pass, 29.IX.2012. B, biotope at Tarmaber Pass; picture showing a plant spot of
Ajuga integrifolia
, 29.IX.2012. C, adult on
A. integrifolia
, 29.IX.2012. D, two adults on
A. integrifolia
, 29.IX.2012. E, copulation, observed in rearing conditions, 01.X.2012. F, egg laying, observed in rearing conditions, 03.X.2012. G, two larvae (above) and a prepupa (below), reared on Chinese cabbage, 31.X.2012; picture showing the variability of body colouration. H, prepupae, entering in offered soil layer, 02.XI.2012. I, Brassicaceae plant on which one larva was collected, at Abay Gorge, 13.X.2011. J, full-grown larva, 15.X.2011 (individual relating to previous picture). K, prepupa, 16.X.2011 (same individual as shown in previous picture). L, cocoon, 20.X.2011 (formed by individual shown in previous picture).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution. Eritrea , Ethiopia (
Fig. 8
D), Yemen .

Host plant.
Brassica oleracea
L. ( Brassicaceae ) (
Benson 1962 : 378
) and other Brassicaceae (see Ecological observations).

Remarks.
Athalia vollenhoveni
(
Fig. 15
) and
A. excisa
are distinguished from all other species of the
A. vollenhoveni
species group by the uniformly flavescent-hyaline wings and the entirely black tergum 1 .
Athalia excisa
is separated from
A. vollenhoveni
by the deeply excised hypopygium (
Figs 3
A, 4 A), and in males the genitalia (
Figs 3
B–C, 4 B–C) are also conspicuously different. Some adults from Tarmaber Pass could be reared during a couple of generations (
Fig. 16
E–H). The larva from Abay Gorge was collected (
13 .X. 2011
;
Fig.
16
I–J) on a young, isolated plant. It molted into a prepupal stage during night (
15–16 .X. 2011
;
Fig. 16
K), built a cocoon after one day (
Fig. 16
L), and a female emerged on
11 .XI. 2011
. In a cage, this adult laid eggs on seedlings of
Sinapis alba
, on which subsequent larvae fed, and two adult males emerged on
10–11 .II. 2012
.
